Comment: a Queen's pawn opening...
?! huh? This is a strange opening choice for Black!
I ignore it for now and go ahead with my own development
Opens up the diagonals for the queen and bishop, but Black seems to have no interest in contesting the centre.
and I've finished with my pawn structure - the d-pawn backed up by the c and e pawns.
Black now makes his own claim to the centre
I bring out my bishop, where it sits and waits for a chance to strike. I guess that's the idea for this opening - defence
?! I guess this would be to block my bishop, but still, it's another strange pawn move from Black
usually, I play Nf3 in this position, but I was worried about the prospect of 5...g5, which could end up having me lose tempo trying to retreat my knight

it's here that I begin to recognise this position - there are some chess players who do this kind of pawn line-up all over the board. I hate it when that's played against me - it leads to some very cramped play... but then again, here it could hold an advantage for Black as his dark-square bishop is a lot more mobile than my own (one of the drawbacks that discouraged me from this opening for awhile)
castling kingside, as I normally do, but maybe that should have waited - I just castled to the area of all Black's pawns.
Black finally develops a piece, but right now it doesn't hold much of a threat against me
Like I've already mentioned, the trouble with this is the lack of mobility of my dark-square bishop - but hopefully White's solid defence should compensate for that
Black brings out his other knight, which prompts me to play...
threatening to drive away his knight, and starting a queen-side attack with my pawns (you know, I'm really starting to like my pawns :) )
White prevents my b-pawn from reaching the b5 square...
so I put more pressure on it. This game is starting to open up a little
? a mistake - White can now do what it intended to do in the first place...
drive away the knight!

? another mistake here - it leave White with a possible future opportunity to attack the knight, as well as leaving the knight with no escape options (the other alternative was Ne7 - definitely the better choice)
